awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Collaborative Research: Mining for Patterns in Graphs and High-Dimensional Data: Achieving the Limits
awd_abstract_narration:
While modern datasets are very large, the amount of information per variable is often relatively small. This includes datasets from genomics, social networks, and many applications in machine learning and artificial intelligence. For instance, in genomics we often track hundreds of thousands of genes, but only have a few hundred independent samples for each one. Similarly, online social networks are massive, but the structure of friendships only gives us a relatively small amount of data per individual. This kind of data is called "high-dimensional", and poses new challenges for mathematics, statistics, and computer science, especially when (as with all real data) they are noisy or incomplete. This project will identify exactly when and how it is mathematically possible to find patterns in these massive but noisy datasets, giving scientists across many fields a useful guide to how much data they need to draw reliable conclusions, and to develop new algorithms that will solve modern data science problems efficiently and optimally.

Through the study of community detection, noisy graph isomorphism, and matrix/tensor factorization, this project will develop a general framework to 1) locate the information-theoretic limit below which the observation is too noisy to detect the underlying pattern, or even to tell if a pattern exists; 2) devise efficient algorithms that succeed all the way down to the lowest possible signal-to-noise ratio; 3) prove that important classes of algorithms need super-polynomial time in certain hard regimes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project has substantially progressed our understanding of mining for patterns in graphs and high-dimensional data. In particular, the PI has developed efficient algorithms for matching correlated graphs with initial seeds and characterized their performance limits, for both ER random graphs and power-law graphs. These results significantly improved the state-of-the-art in terms of matching accuracy, graph sparsity, and the required number of initial seeds. Furthermore, the PI has characterized the sharp information-theoretic thresholds for both testing and matching correlated graphs. These results reveal an intriguing all-or-nothing phase transition. Surprisingly, the same type of phase transition is also shown in high-dimensional sparse linear regression. However, there exists a large gap between the information-theoretic limits and the existing performance guarantees of polynomial-time algorithms. To provide evidence for the existence of the hard regime, the PI has investigated the optimal low-degree test under the context of graph matching. Finally, the PI has studied the problem of recovering various hidden subgraphs that lack low-rank structures, including Hamiltonian cycles, k-nearest neighbor graphs, and bipartite matchings. Both sharp information-theoretic limits and optimal algorithms are developed. An infinite-order phase transition is shown for recovering bipartite matching with exponential random weights.   

The PI has furthered the educational goals of the present research project through mentoring both undergraduate, graduate students and post-docs. He advised an undergraduate student under the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. The research findings in this project have been incorporated into a new Ph.D. class on Statistical Inference in Graphs and a survey article on information-theoretic and computational limits of planted models. The PI also has organized many seminars, workshops, and invited sessions at various conferences. The developed algorithms have been made available on the PI’s website and Github. 


Last Modified: 10/23/2021
Modified by: Jiaming Xu
